paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does the Earth-sized rocky exoplanet TRAPPIST-1 b, which orbits an M dwarf under strong stellar irradiation, retain a discernible atmosphere?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Observed System
datasets_or_cohorts.description: The actual observational data of TRAPPIST-1 b using JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy over an orbital phase curve.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Bare-rock Null Scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: An atmosphere-free, bare-rock model used as a comparison baseline, which assumes minimal heat redistribution and no atmospheric greenhouse effect.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich Atmosphere Model
datasets_or_cohorts.description: An atmosphere retrieval model that includes a significant concentration of CO2 to test for the presence of a greenhouse gas absorption signature in the spectrum.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich Atmosphere Model
datasets_or_cohorts.description: An atmosphere retrieval model with an oxidized composition, used to check if the data can constrain atmospheres where the CO2 signature is weaker or different.

major_limitations: This is a single-planet study and does not establish atmospheric prevalence across all M-dwarf rocky planets. (L47)
Retrieval assumptions (circulation, opacity priors, cloud treatment) significantly affect the resulting quantitative posteriors. (L48)
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can introduce bias into the measurement of weak spectral features. (L49)
Constraints derived from the night-side of the planet are considerably weaker compared to the day-side constraints in the current observational dataset. (L50)
